misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Missing letter-grade ranges and outputs (only pass/fail implemented)
misconceptions.description: The student does not implement the required A/B/C/D/F letter-grade mapping with the specified numeric ranges. Instead, they treat the problem as a simple pass/fail classifier using thresholds at 60 and 70, and they print the string "passing" or "F" rather than the required letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this problem by checking whether the grade is at least 70 or at least 60 and then printing "passing" or "F"; detailed ranges for A, B, C, and D (and printing those letters) are not necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement all specified numeric ranges and map them to the correct single-letter outputs: A for 90–100, B for 80–89, C for 70–79, D for 60–69, and F for below 60. Each branch should print exactly the corresponding letter (e.g., "A", "B", etc.), not a generic word like "passing".
symptoms: Program never prints any of the required letter grades A, B, C, or D.
Logic only distinguishes grades based on thresholds at 60 and 70.
Outputs are the words "passing" or "F" instead of the letters specified in the problem statement.
No handling for distinct A, B, C, and D ranges; they are all effectively collapsed into "passing" or "F".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or reusing a generic pass/fail pattern instead of carefully implementing the specified grade-to-letter mapping. The student may be focusing on checking a minimal threshold for passing rather than translating the full written specification into code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and, on paper, write out the numeric ranges and their corresponding letters. Then implement an if/else-if/else chain that checks the ranges in order from highest to lowest (A first down to F), and for each branch print exactly the correct single-letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code never references A, B, C, or D, and only prints "passing" or "F", which is inconsistent with the very explicit problem statement. This strongly suggests the student implemented a different, simpler specification (pass/fail) instead of the required full mapping.

evidence.note: This code only distinguishes between grades >=70 (prints "passing") and some other cases printing "F". It never implements the A/B/C/D ranges or prints letter grades as required.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of else binding in nested if statements
misconceptions.description: The student nests an if inside another if without braces and places an else aligned with the outer if, apparently expecting it to handle grades below 60. In Java, the else binds to the nearest unmatched if (the inner one), so the else branch only runs when grade >= 60 and grade < 70. As a result, grades below 60 produce no output at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: Because I wrote the else aligned under the outer if (grade >= 60), it will execute when the outer condition is false (i.e., for grade < 60).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an else always associates with the closest preceding unmatched if, not with the if it is visually aligned under. Without braces, your code is parsed as `if (grade >= 60) { if (grade >= 70) ... else ... }`, so the else only runs when the inner if is false and the outer if is true. To have an else correspond to the outer condition, you must structure the if/else-if/else chain explicitly, usually with braces.
symptoms: For grade values below 60, the program prints nothing at all instead of printing "F".
For grade values between 60 and 69, the program prints "F", even though these should be D (and, in any case, are not below 60).
Behavior indicates the else is attached to the inner if (grade >= 70) rather than handling all grades below 60.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how Java associates else clauses with if statements, likely assuming that indentation or visual alignment controls the association rather than the actual syntax rules. The missing braces make this error more likely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use braces when nesting if statements, especially while learning: `if (...) { ... } else { ... }`. Draw or rewrite your code with explicit braces to see which if each else belongs to. Remember that in Java the else always pairs with the closest previous unmatched if.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure of the nested if without braces and the misbehavior for grades < 60 are classic signs of misunderstanding else binding; this is a well-known beginner pitfall.

evidence.note: Because there are no braces, the else is bound to `if (grade >= 70)` rather than `if (grade >= 60)`. This causes no output for grades below 60 and an incorrect F for 60–69.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Solving a different problem (distance formula instead of pure grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: After the minimal grade-related logic, the program prompts for coordinates of two points and computes the distance between them. This behavior is unrelated to the grade-calculator specification and produces extra prompts and outputs that are not part of the required task.
misconceptions.student_belief: Including additional distance-calculation logic (from another exercise or example) in this program is acceptable, even though the current task only requires reading a grade and printing a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program for this question should focus solely on the grade-calculation behavior: read one grade, determine the correct letter according to the given ranges, and print that letter. Additional unrelated input prompts and computations (like distance between two points) should not be included, because they change the behavior and interface from what the specification describes.
symptoms: Program prints prompts such as "Enter x1 and y1:" and "Enter x2 and y2:" that are not mentioned in the problem statement.
Program requires additional numeric inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) beyond the single grade.
Program computes and prints a distance value, which is unrelated to letter grades.
Overall I/O behavior does not match the sample run; the required grade output is mixed with extra debugging and distance output.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copying and modifying a template from a different assignment (a distance calculator) without removing the old logic, or misunderstanding that each question should have a focused program with only the specified behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For each assignment, start from a clean file or carefully remove any leftover code from other problems. Compare your program's prompts and outputs directly to the sample run: they should match in structure and purpose. Keep one program focused on one task unless explicitly told otherwise.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The distance-formula logic and its prompts clearly belong to a different standard CS1 exercise and are entirely unrelated to the stated grade-calculator requirements, making it very likely the student reused code inappropriately.

evidence.note: All of this code implements a distance calculator with debug output, which is not part of the grade-calculator specification and changes the program's required I/O behavior.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Dangling Else Misassociation in Nested If
misconceptions.description: The student implemented nested `if` statements without curly braces, causing the final `else` statement to bind only to the immediate preceding `if` condition (`grade >= 70`). This is known as the 'dangling else' problem and leads to incorrect logic where grades 60-69 (which satisfy the outer `if` but fail the inner `if`) incorrectly execute the `else` block (printing 'F').
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the final `else` block is associated with the outermost `if` statement (`grade >= 60`) when using nested `if` statements without explicit block scoping (curly braces).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java (and C/C++), an `else` clause always binds to the nearest preceding unmatched `if`. To control the scope and ensure the intended flow, block statements (`{}`) must be used.
symptoms: Incorrect classification of boundary cases (e.g., grade 65 outputs 'F')
Ambiguous control flow in nested conditionals
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of Java's block scoping rules for `if-else` structures when curly braces are omitted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use curly braces `{}` around the body of `if` and `else` statements, especially in nested structures, to clearly define the scope and prevent unintended 'dangling else' binding.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code segment clearly exhibits the classic dangling else structure, resulting in demonstrably incorrect grade classification for the D range (60-69).

evidence.note: The 'else' on line 8 incorrectly binds to 'if (grade >= 70)', causing grades 60-69 to incorrectly output 'F'.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Incomplete Cascading Logic for Range Classification
misconceptions.description: The student's conditional structure only checks two thresholds (60 and 70) and outputs 'passing' or 'F', completely failing to implement checks for A (90-100), B (80-89), and D (60-69), and fails to output the required letter grades (A, B, C, D). Furthermore, grades below 60 are completely missed by the structure.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that checking only a few major thresholds (like 60 and 70) is sufficient to handle the full grading scale, possibly misunderstanding the requirement to differentiate five distinct ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To correctly classify five distinct, sequential ranges (A, B, C, D, F), a complete `if-else if-else` structure is required, or compound conditions must be used, ensuring every boundary (60, 70, 80, 90) is checked and the correct output is generated.
symptoms: Missing checks for upper grade ranges (A, B)
Outputs 'passing' instead of A, B, or C
Grades below 60 produce no output related to the task
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to map the problem requirements (five grades) into the appropriate sequential conditional structure.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use `else if` to chain conditions in descending order of grade. Start with grade >= 90 (A), then else if grade >= 80 (B), and so on, ending with a final `else` for F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student only implemented two levels of checks and failed to produce the required A, B, C, D, F outputs, making the solution fundamentally incorrect for the problem.

evidence.note: This structure only identifies >70 (as 'passing') and 60-69 (as 'F'), ignoring the A and B ranges and the required letter grades C and D.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Dangling Else & Incomplete Multi-Way Conditionals
misconceptions.description: The student attempted to use nested if statements to check grade thresholds but did not account for the dangling else problem. The else clause pairs with the outer if, not the inner if. This causes the logic to fail: for grades 60-69, neither branch executes (no output); for grades 70+, only 'passing' is printed without distinguishing A, B, C, or D.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that nested if statements can be used to check multiple thresholds in sequence: if grade >= 60, then check if grade >= 70; if the first condition fails, print F. They do not account for the dangling else problem or that their nested structure does not cover all cases.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Java's dangling else rule pairs else with the nearest preceding if. For multi-way conditionals checking non-overlapping ranges, use if-else-if chains with explicit braces or independent conditions. For example: if (grade >= 90) { A } else if (grade >= 80) { B } else if (grade >= 70) { C } else if (grade >= 60) { D } else { F }
symptoms: Grades 60-69 produce no output
Grades 70+ print 'passing' instead of letter grades A/B/C/D
Only F is printed for grades below 60
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of Java's dangling else rule and how nested if statements work. The student did not recognize that their nested structure left gaps (e.g., 60-69 range) and conflated thresholds with final outputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use an if-else-if chain instead. Check from highest to lowest threshold: if (grade >= 90) print A; else if (grade >= 80) print B; else if (grade >= 70) print C; else if (grade >= 60) print D; else print F. Use braces to make control flow explicit.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code shows clear evidence of nested if misuse with a dangling else. The output behavior (no result for 60-69, 'passing' for 70+) perfectly demonstrates this specific misconception. High confidence.

evidence.note: The else pairs with the outer if (grade >= 60), not the inner if. For 60-69: outer condition is true but inner is false, so nothing executes. For 70+: prints 'passing' without distinguishing letter grades. For <60: prints 'F'.

Output format is missing the 'Letter grade: ' prefix
No distinction between A, B, C, D

User receives no indication that input is expected

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Missing letter-grade ranges and outputs
misconceptions.description: Instead of mapping numeric grades 0-100 into the five required letter ranges (A, B, C, D, F) and printing "Letter grade: X", the program only distinguishes between a generic "passing" message and "F". No explicit checks for A, B, C, or D ranges are implemented, so most grades do not produce the required letter-grade output.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that for this problem it is sufficient to check if a grade is at least 70 and print "passing", and otherwise print "F" for failing cases, without creating separate conditions for A, B, C, and D letter grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must partition the full 0–100 numeric grade range into five disjoint intervals (90–100: A, 80–89: B, 70–79: C, 60–69: D, below 60: F) and, using an if/else-if/else chain or equivalent, print the corresponding letter grade in the required format, e.g. "Letter grade: B".
symptoms: The strings "A", "B", "C", and "D" never appear in the program output.
Grades between 70 and 100 produce the message "passing" instead of a specific letter grade.
Grades between 60 and 69 produce "F" instead of "D".
Grades below 60 produce no output at all from the grading logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely a misunderstanding of the problem requirements, simplifying the grading logic to a pass/fail check rather than implementing all required letter-grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the grading section as a clear if/else-if chain that checks the ranges in order, for example: if (grade >= 90) { System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } down to an else that prints "Letter grade: F".
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code never references any letter grades and only prints "passing" or "F", which clearly does not satisfy the specified five-range letter-grade behavior.

evidence.note: Only checks for grade >= 60 and >= 70, and prints "passing" or "F"; no conditions or outputs for A/B/C/D letter grades or the "Letter grade: X" format.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of else binding in nested if without braces
misconceptions.description: The student writes a nested if without braces, causing the else to bind to the inner if (grade >= 70) rather than to the outer if (grade >= 60). As a result, grades between 60 and 69 incorrectly print "F", while grades below 60 produce no grade output at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that the else corresponds to the outer condition if (grade >= 60), likely guided by indentation rather than Java's actual if-else binding rules.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an else always associates with the closest preceding unmatched if, regardless of indentation. To have an else correspond to an outer if that contains another if, you must use braces to group the inner if and its body.
symptoms: For a grade like 65, the program prints "F" even though 65 should be a passing grade (D).
For a grade like 50, the program prints nothing, even though it should print an F.
The observable behavior matches an implicit structure of if (grade >= 60) { if (grade >= 70) ... else ... }.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how Java pairs else branches with if statements when braces are omitted, and reliance on indentation instead of explicit block delimiters.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use braces when nesting if statements, especially when you intend an else to belong to an outer condition. For example: if (grade >= 60) { if (grade >= 70) { ... } } else { ... }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure is a classic "dangling else" situation, and the observed output ranges (C/D grades become F, true F grades have no output) are exactly what results from misbinding the else.

evidence.note: Because there are no braces, the else attaches to the inner if (grade >= 70); this makes 60–69 print "F" and <60 print nothing, contrary to the intended grading logic.

misconceptions.name: Dangling Else Misassociation (Grade Logic)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented nested if statements without using braces ({}), causing the 'else' block (intended for F grade) to associate only with the innermost 'if' statement (grade >= 70). This means the 'F' grade is only printed for grades between 60 and 69, instead of grades below 60.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the 'else' statement at line 10 corresponds to the outer 'if (grade >= 60)', or they misunderstand how nested conditionals without braces are parsed in Java.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java (and C/C++), an 'else' binds to the closest preceding unmatched 'if'. To correctly apply the 'else' to the outer guard (grade >= 60), the inner 'if' block must be enclosed in braces, or better, the logic should use `if-else if-else` structure covering all ranges sequentially.
symptoms: Incorrect output for grades 0-59 (prints nothing)
Incorrect output for grades 60-69 (prints 'F')
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of Java's scope rules for control structures, specifically the 'dangling else' problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use curly braces {} to enclose blocks of code belonging to 'if' and 'else' statements, especially when nesting. Alternatively, restructure the grading logic using `if/else if/else` to manage grade ranges correctly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure is unambiguously a classic dangling else issue, which severely breaks the core logic for Q3.

evidence.note: The 'else' on line 10 binds to the 'if (grade >= 70)', executing only when grade >= 60 AND grade < 70 (i.e., grades 60-69).

symptoms: Grade of 95 outputs 'passing' instead of 'Letter grade: A'
Grade of 85 outputs 'passing' instead of 'Letter grade: B'
No way to distinguish A, B, and C grades in the output
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not design the conditional logic to handle all five ranges. They created a minimal solution checking only >= 60 and >= 70 without realizing they needed finer granularity to separate the upper grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add nested or chained conditions: if (grade >= 90) for A, else if (grade >= 80) for B, else if (grade >= 70) for C, and so on.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows no conditions checking >= 90 or >= 80. Tracing through with grade = 95 or 85 shows both produce 'passing' output, confirming the student cannot distinguish A from B.

evidence.note: Code only checks grade >= 70. To distinguish A (90-100) and B (80-89), explicit conditions for these ranges are required.
